message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a possible intussusception. The next best test to confirm this diagnosis would be an abdominal ultrasound, which can show the characteristic "target sign." Peripheral blood culture, KUB radiograph, and CBC with differential are not specific tests for intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest intussusception, which is best diagnosed by abdominal ultrasound. Peripheral blood culture is not typically necessary for diagnosis. Kidney, ureter, bladder radiograph and complete blood count with differential would not be helpful in diagnosing intussusception.

We refer to PubMed Health for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible intussusception, which is a medical emergency. Abdominal ultrasound is the next best diagnostic test to confirm or rule out this condition. Peripheral blood culture, kidney, ureter, bladder radiograph, and complete blood count with differential are not helpful in diagnosing intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of bloody stool and a palpable mass suggests Intussusception, a medical emergency that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment. Abdominal ultrasound is the most sensitive imaging modality for diagnosing Intussusception. The other options have no relevance to the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible intussusception, and an abdominal ultrasound is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm this diagnosis. A kidney, ureter, bladder radiograph or complete blood count with differential would not provide enough information to confirm the diagnosis. Peripheral blood culture is not necessary in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest an intestinal obstruction, and the palpable mass could be indicative of intussusception. The next best diagnostic test is abdominal ultrasound, which is the best way to diagnose intussusception in infants. Peripheral blood culture and kidney, ureter, bladder radiograph are not indicated for this condition, and a complete blood count with differential may not provide a definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen suggests the need for an imaging test. Among the options, abdominal ultrasound is the most appropriate diagnostic test to visualize the mass and determine if it is an intussusception, which is the most likely diagnosis. Peripheral blood culture, kidney/ureter/bladder radiograph, and complete blood count with differential would not provide enough information to diagnose an intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest intussusception, which can be confirmed with an abdominal ultrasound. Peripheral blood cultures are not necessary in this case, and a kidney, ureter, bladder radiograph or complete blood count with differential are not the best diagnostic tests for intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of bloody and mucous stool, along with a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, suggests intussusception. Abdominal ultrasound is the best diagnostic test for confirming the diagnosis of intussusception in pediatric patients. Peripheral blood culture and complete blood count may be ordered to rule out infection or inflammation, but they do not confirm the diagnosis of intussusception. A kidney, ureter, bladder radiograph is not a useful test for this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the symptoms and physical exam findings, the next best diagnostic test would be an abdominal ultrasound to evaluate for possible intussusception. Peripheral blood culture and kidney, ureter, bladder radiograph would not be helpful in diagnosing intussusception. A complete blood count with differential may show elevated white blood cell count and hemoglobin, but it is not specific to intussusception.
